claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: the manufacturing process can lead to egg adapted mutations in the magglutinin (HA) protein in IIV, that could result in altered an ...iff i (VE) i h i l i
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote directly states that the manufacturing process for egg-based vaccines can lead to egg-adapted mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) protein, which could result in altered vaccine effectiveness (VE), supporting the claim that mutations during production may reduce effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: Repeat vaccination with egg based influenza vaccines could preferentially boost antibodies targeting the egg adapted epi topes and reduce immuno- gen i city to circulating viruses.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote explains that egg-based vaccines can boost immune responses to egg-adapted epitopes (mutations from production) rather than to the circulating viruses, which can reduce the vaccine's effectiveness.

extracted_evidence.quote: have reported that Q223 R egg adapted change at the HA head domain of A (H1 N1) pdm09 virus can promote virus replication in eggs, alter antigen i city and influence immune response 37 42.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote provides a specific example of an egg-adapted mutation (Q223R) that occurs during production, which can alter the antigenicity of the virus and influence the immune response, thus potentially reducing vaccine effectiveness.
